title: Staff Lifecycle: Recruitment, Induction, Appraisal, Professional Development, and Wellbeing

content.text: The quality of student learning is strongly linked to staff quality. This section defines a full staff lifecycle system to attract, develop, support, evaluate, and retain high-performing personnel in alignment with school mission and compliance standards.

content.title: Staff Lifecycle Objectives
items: Recruit qualified and mission-aligned staff through fair processes.
Provide structured induction and early-career support.
Use appraisal and coaching to improve instructional practice.
Strengthen professional growth through continuous development.
Protect staff wellbeing and sustain retention.

content.text: Strategic workforce planning ensures the school has the right people in the right roles at the right time, supporting continuity and educational quality.

content.title: Annual Workforce Planning Cycle
items: Review enrollment projections, program growth, and timetable requirements.
Analyze current staffing profile, qualifications, and role coverage gaps.
Forecast vacancies from contract end dates, attrition risk, and leave patterns.
Set recruitment priorities and budget requirements for the next cycle.
Approve staffing plan through Principal, GM, and governance process.

content.title: Planning Inputs
rows: Determine teacher demand by year and subject
Map specialist roles and program needs
Balance contact hours and planning time

content.text: Recruitment combines international and local channels to secure qualified educators and support staff while maintaining safer recruitment standards.

content.title: Recruitment Sources
items: International platforms and professional networks for Cambridge subject teachers.
Indonesian universities, teacher associations, and national job portals.
Eduversal internal mobility and referral pathways across partner schools.
School-branded careers page and targeted talent outreach.

content.title: Selection Process
items: Role-based screening of CV, qualifications, and employment history.
Structured interviews (including safeguarding and pedagogy scenarios).
Teaching demonstration or competency task where applicable.
Reference checks and background/safeguarding verification.
Final decision with documented rationale and approval trail.

content.text: Contracting and onboarding must comply with Indonesian labor law while ensuring clarity of duties, rights, performance expectations, and school standards.

content.title: Common Contract Models
rows: New hires, temporary coverage, project roles
Defined duration and renewal constraints under labor law
Long-term staff after successful probation cycle
Indefinite term with due-process termination requirements

content.title: Onboarding Essentials
items: Contract briefing and policy acknowledgment (including safeguarding and conduct).
Systems setup: payroll, benefits, IT access, HR records.
Role orientation: curriculum expectations, reporting lines, and duty schedule.
Assignment of mentor and induction timeline.

content.text: All new teachers complete a structured one-year induction to support instructional quality, professional confidence, and integration into school culture.

content.title: Induction Components
items: Orientation to school mission, values, policies, and operational systems.
Curriculum and assessment alignment, including Cambridge and Indonesian requirements.
Classroom management and student support expectations.
Mentoring and scheduled coaching observations.
Termly check-ins and evidence-based progress review.

content.title: Expected Outcomes
items: Secure classroom routines and lesson quality.
Accurate assessment and reporting practice.
Strong collaboration with colleagues and families.
Readiness for full appraisal cycle participation.

content.text: Professional development is delivered through network, school-based, and external pathways to improve teaching proficiency and leadership capacity.

content.title: Core PD Pathways
items: DTP (Development of Teaching Proficiency) and Educamp modules.
Cambridge International PD and subject-specific training.
In-school PLCs, lesson study, and peer observation cycles.
External conferences and specialist workshops.

content.title: PD Planning Expectations
rows: Aligned to appraisal goals and school priorities

content.text: The appraisal cycle combines administrative standards, classroom practice evidence, and work inspection to support accountability and growth.

content.title: Appraisal Components
rows: Lesson plans, student work, records, communication

content.title: Cycle Stages
items: Orientation and rubric briefing (Term 1).
Goal setting with appraiser (Term 1).
Mid-year review and evidence check (Term 2).
Formal observations and feedback (Terms 2-3).
Final appraisal meeting and next-cycle planning (Term 3).

content.title: Rating Scale
items: Distinguished (4)
Proficient (3)
Basic (2)
Unsatisfactory (1)

content.text: Goals must follow SMART criteria and be aligned to student outcomes, school priorities, and professional growth needs.

content.title: Goal Structure
items: 1-2 professional practice goals each year.
1 student learning goal with measurable evidence.
Action steps, milestones, and required resources.
Progress evidence logged in appraisal documentation system.

content.title: Growth Plan Evidence
items: Observation feedback and coaching notes.
Student data (pre/post assessments, EASE, class evidence).
PD completion and implementation artifacts.
Reflective self-assessment and revised targets.

content.text: Mentoring and coaching provide sustained, practice-focused support for new, experienced, and aspiring leaders.

items: New teacher mentoring throughout first-year induction.
Peer coaching cycles for targeted instructional refinement.
Leadership coaching for subject leaders and principals.
Coaching culture grounded in trust, reflection, and actionable feedback.

content.text: Staff wellbeing is a strategic quality priority. Schools must proactively manage workload, psychological safety, and sustainable professional expectations.

content.title: Wellbeing Commitments
items: Reasonable teaching loads and protected planning time.
Balanced duty allocation and reduction of unnecessary meetings.
Access to wellbeing support and counseling pathways.
Annual workload and communication audit based on staff feedback.
Leadership modeling of healthy professional boundaries.

content.text: Performance concerns are addressed through staged support, evidence-based expectations, and fair procedural management.

content.title: Response Pathway
items: Identify concern indicators from appraisal, student outcomes, conduct, or policy compliance.
Hold informal improvement conversation and diagnose root causes.
Provide targeted support (mentoring, PD, adjusted duties) where appropriate.
Escalate to formal Performance Improvement Plan (PIP) if concerns persist.
Review outcomes against timeline and determine next decision (close, extend, or formal HR action).

content.title: PIP Minimum Elements
items: Specific performance gaps and expected standards.
Timeline, checkpoints, and evidence requirements.
Assigned support mechanisms and responsible supervisors.
Clear consequence pathway if improvement is not achieved.

content.text: Retention strategy focuses on compensation fairness, culture, leadership quality, and career growth. Exit management ensures knowledge continuity and policy compliance.

content.title: Retention Priorities
items: Competitive and benchmarked compensation and benefits.
Recognition systems and supportive leadership practices.
Career pathways and leadership opportunities.
Collaborative culture and transparent communication.

content.title: Exit Management Steps
items: Receive formal resignation/contract-end confirmation.
Conduct handover, records transfer, and class continuity planning.
Complete exit interview and retention insight capture.
Finalize clearance, payroll, and compliance documentation.

content.title: Recruitment and Employment Evidence
items: Workforce plans and approved staffing budgets.
Job postings, interview records, and selection rationale.
Background checks, references, contracts, and onboarding records.

content.title: Development and Performance Evidence
items: Induction schedules, mentor logs, and completion records.
Appraisal forms, observation notes, ratings, and growth plans.
PD attendance, certificates, and transfer-to-practice evidence.
PIP records, support plans, and outcome documentation.

content.title: Wellbeing, Retention, and Exit Evidence
items: Staff wellbeing survey results and workload audit reports.
Retention metrics and turnover analysis.
Exit interview summaries and handover/clearance records.

content.title: Principal
resp: Holds overall accountability for staff quality, culture, and compliance.
Approves workforce planning, hiring decisions, and appraisal implementation.
Leads performance management, retention strategy, and staff wellbeing oversight.

content.title: General Manager / Yayasan
resp: Approves staffing budgets and strategic workforce priorities.
Ensures legal compliance and governance assurance across lifecycle processes.
Supports leadership appointments and risk escalations.

content.title: HR / People Operations
resp: Administers contracts, records, benefits, and legal documentation.
Coordinates recruitment logistics and onboarding compliance.
Maintains data dashboards for staffing, appraisal, and retention metrics.

content.title: Subject Leaders and Appraisers
resp: Conduct observations, coaching, and performance feedback cycles.
Co-design goals and monitor evidence-based progress.
Identify support needs and escalate concerns early.

content.title: Teachers and Staff
resp: Engage actively in induction, PD, appraisal, and coaching activities.
Meet professional standards, policy expectations, and student-centered practice.
Contribute to a respectful, collaborative, and wellbeing-supportive culture.
